title: Grade 11 - Dynamics of Human Relationships HHD3O (2013)
subject: Social Science and Humanities

document.title: Grade 11 - Dynamics of Human Relationships HHD3O (2013)

30097E3B497741F0B87C7482F7EC7410.description: design and implement a social-action initiative to promote healthy relationships (e.g., a campaign against bullying, discrimination, hate propaganda, or homophobia; a campaign to raise cultural awareness and understanding; an initiative to form a student equity and human rights club; a campaign to address community environmental concerns or gender-related issues)

C9D4DC0D90AD4FD2B36B3248D69B6161.description: assess the effectiveness of a variety of social-action initiatives that promote healthy relationships (e.g., letter-writing campaigns, petitions, brochures, videos, websites, art works, music, posters, drama productions, workshops)

1779872261B841FBB7417438E3F205D1.description: outline various ways in which individuals can enhance relationships through community involvement (e.g., through mentoring programs, consensus-building initiatives, volunteering, advocating for the rights of others)

9BBBBC3AB3A446F1B196FCE6CA936432.description: analyse the benefits of being part of a multicultural community

A336611870AA4CCDBFC6788CAA321C3C.description: Enhancing Relationships through Community Involvement: analyse and assess social-action initiatives that support or contribute to healthy relationships and/or healthy communities, and design and implement an initiative of their own.

B3BCD465906841B9AC4C2D3A374331E7.description: explain why conflicts that are based on infringements of rights and/or that involve a power imbalance (e.g., harassment, homophobia, bullying) cannot be effectively resolved using informal conflict-resolution strategies

C2E3DBC0DCFE4A589EB60FC0B0E3AE5E.description: identify and describe the different strategies used in conflict resolution (e.g., showing mutual respect, confronting the problem, identifying/ defining the basis of the conflict, communicating understanding of another's perspective, considering alternatives, agreeing on a workable solution, continuing to evaluate the situation)

E460E16E94EF4404A549E9F969543C22.description: identify and demonstrate (e.g., in role playing, in real situations) constructive and respectful techniques for resolving various types of interpersonal conflicts

AF63E44077D946A8A416CFC54F02B256.description: identify various approaches that may be used to effectively resolve conflicts (e.g., Aboriginal healing circles, compromise and negotiation, avoidance of/removal from a situation, restorative justice processes, mediation, peer mediation, letter writing, techniques learned through assertiveness training)

013B4DBC70964604BA396AFF31D18573.description: identify factors that can lead to interpersonal conflicts (e.g., jealousy, differing opinions, differing values, differing personalities)

342F80691F08496C8382152252387710.description: describe how conflicts arise in various human interactions

FD5F495436C2448383FB134C4B32F2EB.description: Resolving Conflicts: demonstrate an understanding of effective strategies for resolving conflicts in human interactions;

852C1CABBB184AB2B68DF5F01BA099FA.description: describe ways in which effective and ineffective communication can affect relationships

CBB15A059633407FB62C396AEC45240F.description: explain why it is important to be aware of the communication styles of cultural groups other than their own (e.g., norms about eye contact, physical contact, and personal space)

FA799DAD10084B8A86F5EE879BA0FE14.description: demonstrate the use of a variety of skills and techniques for communicating effectively (e.g., listening actively; maintaining open body language; taking turns in conversation; following accepted etiquette for telephone, cellphone, and Internet communication; setting clear boundaries)

66B0DF59700045FEBB4E547A965730E1.description: describe behaviours and other factors that can interfere with effective communication (e.g., interruptions, judgements, angry intonation, too great or too little physical distance, noise, blaming, sarcasm, threats, prejudice, gossip, accusations, lies, rumours, inappropriate use of technology, cultural misunderstandings, bias)

67BABE6CDF194020A36DB87336F82BB4.description: describe the three basic styles of communication (i.e., passive, aggressive, assertive)

A9F8DF7D0A014416907F4334D755E470.description: identify the components of non-verbal communication (e.g., body language and manner of self-presentation, eye contact, physical distance, culture-based behaviour)

8C780AAE17C74F61A0A7D9C540DF00F5.description: identify the components of verbal communication (e.g., choice of vocabulary, tone of voice, volume, rhythm and pace of speech, culture-based modes of address)

2EC1CBB6E90440D3B5E5F99E42AFC233.description: apply appropriate decision-making processes effectively in a variety of relationships (e.g., intimate relationships, multicultural relationships, multigenerational relationships, multi-faith relationships, employment relationships)

12784BDB578342ADBDEE4CA15A9AA1A9.description:
identify and consult a variety of credible
resources for information and assistance in
making decisions (e.g., teachers, guidance counsellors, Health Canada, Dietitians of Canada, the
Vanier Institute of the Family, local health units,
the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health, the
Centre for Prevention Science, the Promoting Relationships and Eliminating Violence Network,
the Centre for Positive Relationships, the World
Health Organization, the World Wildlife Fund,
Native friendship centres, multicultural centres,
Mothers Against Drunk Drivers Canada)

6933B334E26F4C8580528055BC22BE25.description: describe factors that affect decision making (e.g., goals, values, priorities, needs, wants, resources, peers, parents, family members, community, school, faith community, media)

CD2B406474BD409D93BDD4AB77691ED6.description: identify steps in the decision-making process (e.g., defining the problem, reviewing goals and values, identifying alternative solutions, weighing the options, choosing a solution, evaluating the results)

6785EF93C94F4BC2AF9139B580696FBE.description: explain the advantages and disadvantages of some common approaches to decision making (e.g., acting on impulse, adopting a laissez-faire attitude, flipping a coin, listing pros and cons, creating a plus/minus/interesting chart)

7931DA1208B84560BB50211FB5384B57.description: Making Decisions: demonstrate an understanding of effective decision-making processes in a variety of social contexts;

0CFCAD06D3CC482098CA8F38B95B2E0D.description: compare and evaluate various strategies for responding to infringements on individual rights (e.g., direct confrontation, complaints to people in positions of authority, official complaints to the Ontario Human Rights Commission)

4ACD944B9DB848F988168725E66169B8.description: describe how rights are allocated among individuals, groups, families, and communities

A052C3BC7BA94C8B94AACD38988902E7.description: explain how various societal factors (e.g., media, peers, socio-economic status, technology, environmental conditions, values, culture, religion, family) extend or limit individual rights and responsibilities

E56269BE91454556B2A68ABBAE3454CD.description: Rights and Responsibilities in Community Context: demonstrate an understanding of the extent of individual rights and responsibilities within the wider community.

07A8226B670C4D08AA37B06435E76982.description: explain the difference between legal and personal rights and responsibilities

EFED7EB35B44496EA600C50CEEDC1099.description: explain the relationship between rights and responsibilities

FE0399DB7CDF4C7396B13CA45BAF7EFC.description: identify the individual's responsibilities in human interactions (e.g., obeying Canada's laws, refraining from infringing on the rights of others, promoting respect for others, encouraging the responsible use of technology)

685CB84842CE4BA094FF3BD59B818045.description: identify the rights of the individual in human interactions as outlined in a variety of laws and policies (e.g., the Ontario Human Rights Code, the Employment Standards Act, the Ontario Environmental Bill of Rights, the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, the Indian Act, the Privacy Act, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights)

FB79DFF32AD34332BD2116B534E18F54.description: Individual Rights and Responsibilities: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of individual rights and responsibilities in human interactions;

49157B5D7E704EDBBD940F24A61ACD0F.description: describe strategies for sustaining various types of relationships as they evolve over time

9908A8754F8947A1A6499C7F8E97B0FE.description: describe strategies and approaches for ending a relationship in a positive manner (e.g., treat the other person with sensitivity, respect, integrity, empathy, and honesty; enable the other person to maintain his or her dignity; communicate face to face; ensure that verbal and non-verbal messages match; listen to their instincts)

D51D69B0EF904BA5850D36DF258400BA.description: identify strategies for dealing with significant change and/or loss in a relationship (e.g., seeking relationship and/or grief counselling, taking time to grieve, confiding in friends, learning acceptance, believing in oneself, developing self-reliance)

5997F5B21C2D4FBA8942639251BD3E13.description: describe strategies and skills for building healthy relationships (e.g., showing empathy, setting realistic expectations, showing respect for others, communicating with openness where possible and appropriate, working to solve problems, seeking counselling, seeking community support, volunteering, giving time and attention to others)

3F2084B9DC064D2D9F98ADD148FE9623.description: Building Healthy Relationships: demonstrate an understanding of skills and strategies that help people to develop and sustain healthy relationships

51DAE8DF8F924DED9B79F63235C735DF.description: describe the impact on human interactions of various changes that are taking place in society (e.g., greater reliance on technology, greater acceptance of independence by and for young people and women, greater cultural diversity in communities, increased sense of environmental responsibility)

554EB6C150C5478E9C137C32B01A1313.description: describe typical gender differences in expectations about relationships (e.g., with respect to monogamy, equity, shared time, loyalty, openness, sexuality)

0A3044174366411297C55EC3AE5319B4.description: describe the challenges that may be experienced in the development of a same-sex relationship but may not be experienced in the development of a heterosexual relationship (e.g., homophobia, pressure to keep the relationship hidden, lack of models in media of adolescents in healthy same-sex relationships)

EE5C1FFB68B2401DB9D70734F7C59706.description: describe some of the ways in which power dynamics can influence behaviour in human interactions

5FBCB546C28D4276B5C6353B4A72A2EB.description: describe values and attitudes that enhance the quality of human interactions (e.g., respect, caring, empathy, trust, honour, honesty)

141568C5C5FF49D0A925F173B6895EE3.description: describe variations in cultural customs and traditions that affect how humans interact (e.g., customs related to greetings, personal space, eye contact, physical distance and/or contact)

60ADBD08036945F490FDE23F8C51417D.description: use various theories about intimacy (e.g., David Olson's seven types of intimacy, Gary Chapman's five love languages, Robert Sternberg's triangular theory of love) to analyse the depth and type of intimacy in different relationships (e.g., acquaintance, friendship, dating, long-term partnership)

F7806AAE4D9E4BBCA1F532CEEE468B62.description: identify the roles people have in various relationships (e.g., parent, child, teen, sibling, grandparent, elder, employee, employer, spouse, friend, student, co-worker, volunteer, significant other, acquaintance)

967970BC96B54765BB6C66239C6C9AD7.description: Dynamics and Challenges That Affect Relationships: demonstrate an understanding of various dynamics and challenges that can affect relationships;

A594229892CF4F60A9847735076E2490.description: describe the benefits and challenges to relationships of increased access to media and technology (e.g., ease of communication through use of cellphones, e-mail, social networking; expectations of immediate response to communications; decreased adult scrutiny of communications)

93D82013CA544004A319E6D99BA4918F.description: analyse ways in which social and cultural factors, including portrayals in the media, shape people's ideas about relationships (e.g., the attitudes and expectations of family, friends, and peers; religious teachings; cultural norms with respect to gender roles; portrayals of intimate/sexual relationships in music videos, video games, or movies, or on television)

716BD47FAB724BBABDEB77EE014C2BB6.description: Social and Cultural Influences: demonstrate an understanding of various social and cultural influences on relationships;

EADA6F93BDB04A739254F34FF9471419.description: explain the contributions healthy relationships make to individual, group, family, and community well-being

8AF10EC8F34D44F89BE44722BC7E9430.description: describe behaviours that characterize unhealthy relationships (e.g., physical and verbal abuse, bullying, sexual harassment, stalking, obsession, possessiveness, intimidation, isolation, financial control, substance abuse, co-dependence)

7CB7490AB9574F1196CA1E60E178E74B.description: identify characteristics of healthy relationships (e.g., equality, independence, trust, empathy, loyalty, respect, intimacy, honour, recognition of the other's value, open communication, stability, confidence, altruism)

2B7ED9F4995246B885B5EE2F48AC92E4.description: describe various types of relationships that people may experience during their lifetime (e.g., parent-child, sibling, peer, friend, studentteacher, spouse, co-worker, dating, intimate, intergenerational, employee-employer, doctor-patient)

6F6BF7806B78459AAB3F0FC65C444F5A.description: Healthy Relationships Over a Lifetime: demonstrate an understanding of the range of relationships people experience over a lifetime and of the differences between healthy and unhealthy relationships;

EBD7F3B168A54CFE94BEE4149BE07F15.description: analyse how both social awareness and physical, psychological, and emotional health affect people's relationships

A461E853B27D41DBB1E5744BCF9932C8.description: analyse how being self-aware affects interpersonal relationships

9FC21DEDE53A49D8AA35F4C906CD2DD8.description: explain the value of recognizing the unique strengths, abilities, and personal qualities of others

68C385A355884A97ABC9C0F785D8CCE5.description: use a variety of means (e.g., personality assessments, aptitude assessments, the Ontario Skills Passport) to identify and assess personal attributes, skills, and talents they have that can help them develop and nurture healthy relationships (e.g., emotional intelligence, listening skills)

0FB866C212044605B0AF6E9FB1B9899E.description: explain how self-concept influences a person's relationships (e.g., with other people, with society in general, with the environment)

36B9EC9C722C4161BCAA4FDE940E9783.description: explain how a strong self-concept and healthy self-esteem contribute to healthy relationships

E79C6A05B1E94ECFA38D6D5C211495F4.description: Self-concept and Healthy Relationships: demonstrate an understanding of how self-concept influences an individual�s interactions with others.

9C71E00FD5504FA79CF35580F8A86252.description: explain ways in which self-concept and self-esteem are interconnected with community and societal beliefs and values

BEF55AC654724333B9C07C23FACF2FFB.description: describe ways to improve self-esteem (e.g., set reasonable goals and take steps to achieve them; participate in physical activities; practise to develop talents; join social groups; connect with a positive peer network)

C912A73A3E624B418DB045E2DE9996C0.description: explain the interrelationship between self-concept, self-esteem, and mental health

6F1A4FD53F7C45F9BB14FB7E1D6F55A5.description: identify the main components of selfconcept (e.g., physical self, academic/occupational self, social self, transpersonal self) and describe some of its characteristics (e.g., self-concept is learned, organized, and dynamic)

73E0C1B9B94B4312A67B039A0CEF956D.description: Self-concept and Self-esteem: explain how self-concept and self-esteem influence personal well-being;

C04DDD73637A4126815300C7D4E2BF27.description: explain what they can do to maintain their personal well-being throughout life, and why it is important to do so

A4FDEF6B9D174551AD0EB13DA918C2DD.description: explain how various factors (e.g., good nutrition, physical activity, a strong support network, awareness of one's experiences and surroundings, lifelong learning, sharing and volunteering) contribute to the development of personal well-being

F713C9FD0169400590DA83568E769AC3.description: identify and describe the various components of personal well-being (e.g., emotional well-being, satisfaction, vitality, resilience, self-esteem, autonomy, competence, engagement, a sense of meaning and purpose, feelings of trust and belonging)

BF4D183706BE4FF79A43888F4334645C.description: Personal Well-Being: demonstrate an understanding of the components of personal well-being, how to achieve and maintain it, and its importance throughout the life course;

965E4F6263B54AFEAA022F65CE72BE05.description: demonstrate an understanding of the general research process by reflecting on and evaluating their own research, inquiry, and communication skills

EB6EE073B5CF45008062C55E07E43228.description: clearly communicate the results of their inquiries (e.g., write clearly, organize ideas logically, use language conventions properly), and follow APA conventions for acknowledging sources (e.g., generate a reference list in APA style)

9A57DF58BA6F4094A9D31EB6BB6E59E0.description: use terms relating to healthy relationships correctly (e.g., self-concept, self-esteem, communication, rights and responsibilities)

778BB41F998E41C0AC63B781FFE4A9F6.description: use an appropriate format (e.g., brochure, flyer, poster, report, multimedia presentation, web page) to communicate the results of their research and inquiry effectively for a specific purpose and audience

A685D0DA856846C59F380E803DEAADFF.description: Communicating and Reflecting: communicate the results of their research and inquiry clearly and effectively, and reflect on and evaluate their research, inquiry, and communication skills.

525283205FC746BC9BE8709DE8EFDFB4.description: synthesize findings and formulate conclusions (e.g., weigh and connect information to determine the answer to their research question)

D69332153B3C4765A700B794B0CE144E.description: demonstrate academic honesty by documenting the sources of all information generated through research

08A3E616FEBF4A0787BF488DA728B214.description: analyse and interpret research information (e.g., compare results of surveys and interviews; determine whether similar information is found in different sources)

3D1CDF74817941949BE76780D7F9035A.description: record and organize information and key ideas using a variety of formats (e.g., notes, graphic organizers, summaries, audio/video/ digital records)

C2D8773E642C4838AD2F0C5C6EEEA243.description: assess various aspects of information gathered from primary and secondary sources (e.g., accuracy, relevance, reliability, inherent values and bias, voice)

719A689D4215494CBED7F96E8F447F5F.description: Processing Information: assess, record, analyse, and synthesize information gathered through research and inquiry;

656057756AB842FC88DBDBB18F459A5C.description: based on preliminary research, for each investigation formulate a hypothesis, thesis statement, or research question, and use it to focus their research

5FAF1F6926C148019FE0E32141773E2D.description: locate and select information relevant to their investigations from a variety of primary sources (e.g., informal interviews and surveys) and secondary sources (e.g., print resources, the Internet, online databases, and other media)

E170D9DAD4844E03A3F8230F8F2FDCDA.description: create appropriate research plans to investigate their selected topics (e.g., outline purpose and method; identify sources of information; develop research tools such as surveys or questionnaires), ensuring that their plans follow guidelines for ethical research

05873B6998994B36A706740339A29A8B.description: Investigating: create research plans, and locate and select information relevant to their chosen topics, using appropriate social science research and inquiry methods;

5BE3653773244B458375D03307A18843.description: formulate effective questions to guide their research and inquiry

33F3FBD417164F0E91BD07DB7035DE55.description: identify key concepts (e.g., through discussion, brainstorming, use of visual organizers) related to their selected topics

2F7A290FD42E47789D0B27B88701B2C6.description: explore a variety of topics related to healthy relationships (e.g., well-being; flourishing versus languishing; mental health and relationships; human rights codes; anti-bullying campaigns) to identify topics for research and inquiry

9447925FCD8F4865A7782727F97E0228.description: Exploring: explore topics related to healthy relationships, and formulate questions to guide their research;
